item.title: Report I-2024010013
item.description:
Report I-2024010013

Identified by scraper @ 2024-05-24T00:37:28+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-09
  • City: Coopersburg
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: PENN TANK LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Driver failed to properly secure a delivery fitting to the UST coupler. During delivery, the fitting dislodged from the coupler allowing release of approx 50 gallons of Fuel Oil affecting the concrete delivery pad and the surrounding asphalt parking lot and a portion of asphalt alley, as well as a 15' x 6" area of grass and dirt. Loose product was contained with spill response materials and booms to prevent spread or storm drain intrusion. Affected areas were treated with oil absorbents that were drummed and removed from the site for disposal by Hepaco.

item.title: Report I-2024010026
item.description:
Report I-2024010026

Identified by scraper @ 2024-05-24T00:37:28+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-06
  • City: Milan
  • State: RI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: AMERICAN AIRLINES GROUP INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Shortly after pushback of American Airlines Flight 199 from the gate, passenger in seat 27L had a powerbank that began to overheat. The crew put the battery in the fire containment bag as a precaution and returned to the gate to remove the battery from the aircraft. The Captain dropped the powerbank out the Flight Deck window to the Ramp. No injuries or damages were reported by the crew. After the battery was removed the aircraft taxied out and departed MXP without further issue. Captain Sorenson wishes to extend thanks to MXP personnel for quick and efficient coordination in handling the Incident. 1

item.description:
Report E-2024050069

Identified by scraper @ 2024-05-23T15:12:17+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-26
  • City: NEW ORLEANS
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 208750
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On April 26th, 2024, at 05:57 hours, personnel in the CSX Gentilly Yard reported a derailment involving loaded tank cars of NA1993, Fuel Oil, Combustible Liquid, PGIII. One of the five derailed tank cars, NATX 301139, was on its side and found to be leaking from the Vacuum Relief Valve. All other derailed cars were found to be leak free. SPSI, a CSX response contractor, and two CSX Managers of Hazardous Materials, responded the incident. Response personnel partially plugged and fully contained the release upon arrival. Once the car was rerailed to an upright the position, the release was stopped. CSX subsequently transloaded, cleaned and purged this car in preparation for the car being dismantled onsite for scrap; repair costs exceeded the value of the car.

  • Description: A Veolia employee was moving containers at the 10 day in-transit storage area with a forklift. The employee needed to move the 951H2 overpack container but due to the issues with utilizing certain drum carts to move these, the employee chose to widen the forks and lift the drum utilizing the edges on the container. Upon lifting with the forks, the container slipped from the forks landing on its side. The employee quickly righted the container with the forklift and tightened the closure, but an estimated 1/2 gallon had leaked out. The 95 gallon overpack contained one 55 gallon drum inside.

The terminal reviewed the BoL and SDS and advised the caller that according to the BoL, the tank is reported as being product RESIDUE with a net weight of 1 pound. The terminal used PPE provided to wipe the spill with absorbents and they were placed it into an 8 gallon metal drum for disposal. The waste was left for the terminal to manage.

item.description:
Report E-2024050354

Identified by scraper @ 2024-05-21T15:12:18+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-05-16
  • City: CHICAGO HEIGHTS
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS FREIGHT, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO-Logistics contacted ERTS regarding (2) crushed and leaking poly drums containing hazardous product, InterCoat® ChemGuard 320L Thor. The drums were shrink-wrapped together by the Shipper and fell over during transit as a result of inadequate preparation for transportation / improper blocking and bracing. This resulted in approximately 1-gallon of product releasing onto the wooden trailer floor in a 5’x5’ area. A Contractor neutralized the release with Acid Gator and overpacked the damaged drums. In total, two 55-gallon DF’s were generated for waste disposal. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were impacted by this incident.

  • Description: Clean Harbors was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 8ft-by-1ft area of the trailer floor and estimated that five (5) gallons of material was released due to improper loading of the freight that damaged two (2) 5-gallon metal pails. Clean Harbors personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area and then gathered the spent material. The recovered impacted absorbents were containerized into one (1) 55-gallon metal drum. The generated waste was transported offsite for disposal. The ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

  • City: CORVALLIS

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Description: On May 14th, the owner of Oregon Valley Farms, Josh, came into the front counter to personally drop off some of these shipments. Previously the station had discovered undeclared shipments that were of similar packages He told the counter agent that he had changed his process that there would be no liquid nitrogen in the package when shipped. After Josh left a visual inspection of the packages he dropped off was done and one hadhad visible frost on the outside of the package. The package was opened up and as suspected there was liquid nitrogen in the package. There was a significant amount of vapor coming out of the package and as the vapor settled liquid nitrogen in the bottom of the package. was visible. The package is being held pending disposition.

Clean Harbors personnel deployed a neutralizer to the impacted area and gathered the spent material. The recovered material was containerized into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

  • Description: A FULLY LABELED HAZMAT PACKAGE WAS DISCOVERED BY AN UNLOADER IN UNLOAD C THAT APPEARED TO BE LEAKING. THE UNLOADER LEFT THE AREA AND NOTIFIED HIS SUPERVISOR. WITHIN 5 MINUTES A DMP RESPONDER ARRIVED DONNING THE CORRECT PPE. USING THE DECISION TREE AND APPROPRIATE RESPONSE SHEET IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE PACKAGE COULD BE SAFELY TRANSPORTED BACK TO THE DMP. UPON FURTHER INSPECTION IT WAS REVEALED THAT THE LIDS ON EACH ONE OF THE INNER 2.5 GALLON PLASTIC CONTAINERS WERE LOOSE BY 1/4 OF A TURN AND 4 OUNCES OF LIQUID HAD LEAKED OUT ONTO THE OUTER CARTON. THERE WAS NO INNER PACKING MATERIAL AND THE OUTER CARTON WAS A DOUBLEWALL FIBERBOARD BOX.

  • Description: Gene Manguso Operations Supervisor called to report a leaking pail on the dock floor in front of Bay Door 28. Gene stated one of his workers when to move the box and found that the box was a little saturated and appeared to have been leaking with in the box. Gene stated the 1 gallon pail in the box was in a bag and looked to have been leaking in the bag. Gene stated he removed the box from the dock floor and placed the pail in a recovery pail and placed it in the OSD. Safety advised Gene any time a spill is found it will need to be reported to safety immediately. Gene stated he would let safet y know before anything is done next time on a spill. Gene stated the product did not spill on the dock floor and was contained to the box. Update Gene stated it looked to be a lose cap on the pail that caused the leak.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal USU experienced a UN1198 Formaldehyde Solution 37% 14% release from a 55-gallon poly drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately all 55-gallons of material released to the trailer and dock floor in a 1’ x 200’ area and a 10’ x 10’ area due to a forklift puncture. The damaged drum was placed into a 95-gallon poly overpack. Absorbents were then deployed to collect all free liquids. A pressure washer was utilized to further clean the impacted doc area and all wastewater was solidified with absorbents. The impacted absorbents and PPE used were then collected and containerized into (4) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: XPO-LOGISTICS contacted ERTS regarding a punctured 15-gallon plastic jug of Liquid Laundry Chlorine Bleach. The container was punctured by a forklift accident. This resulted in an estimated 15-gallon release of hazardous product onto the wooden trailer floor and a the concrete beneath the trailer. The trailer floor was impacted in an approximate area of 8’x6’ and the concrete beneath the trailer was impacted in an approximate area of 9’x21’. A Contractor was dispatched to assist in the clean-up and used oil dry and absorbent pads. Two drums of waste were generated for disposal that included the overpacked, damaged jug and the impacted absorbents. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were impacted by this incident.

  • Description: On May 9, 2024, two (2) 330-gallon totes of UN3266 had damaged caps and released approximately one (1) ounce of product to the surface of the totes. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Alpha-Omega Training and Compliance (AOTC) to remediate the impacted site. Crews replaced both caps on the two (2) totes and verified the seals. AOTC used a baking soda solution and absorbent pads to clean and neutralize the impacted tote surfaces. All waste was collected and containerized into one (1) 5-gallon bucket and staged onsite for disposal.

R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted trailer and pavement and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized eight (8) 55-gallon drums. The response team was dispatched to the sight arriving around 0200ct. They then dawned the appropriate PPE and began unloading the trailer to reach the container that was leaking. They found that the securement strap where it was secured to the wall of the trailer had rubbed a hole in the chime of the drum. The team then proceeded to place the damaged drum into a salvage drum and collected the released material with absorbents and then disposed of in the appropriate manner. The clean up was completed at 0800ct.

The customer handled clean up. • Turns out her hose was past the 1 year inspection interval we require on the hoses. An inspection of the hose showed no obvious signs of deterioration and appear to be age related

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XCN experienced a UN2672 Steammate NA1324 release from a 330-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 50-gallons of product released to a 23' x 8' area of the trailer floor and a 25' x 10' area of the concrete lot below. The release was caused by the tote falling on its side as a result of improper loading. The material was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one. Absorbent and vinegar were deployed and worked into the impacted areas to clean and neutralize the release. The impacted absorbents were containerized into (4) 55-gallon poly drums. The damaged tote was cut up and containerized into a cubic yard box. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 4500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: UTLX 125128 was reported by PUC inspector of possible dried material near BOV. Contractor was hired to investigate and found no issue with BOV but car had dried spots on the car. Contractor proceeded to the top of car and further investigation found frangible disk was ruptured. When removed to replace contractor found that two ruptured disk were in place. Disks were removed and a new disk was applied. Car was cleaned and returned to transportation.

item.title: Report X-2024050580
item.description:
Report X-2024050580

Identified by scraper @ 2024-05-17T21:11:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-13
  • City: GEISMAR
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 16500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On April 13, 2024 at approximately 22:30 CDT during switching operations on the south end of the CN Geismar Yard, a CN transportation crew member observed vapors emitting from the top of tank car RCRX 2718 (Load / Hydrochloric Acid / UN 1789 / PG II / UN 1789). The CN Dangerous Goods Officer was notified of the incident and responded to the rail yard to investigate. The DGO inspection revealed a small amount of liquid pooled in the bowl of the external spring safety relief valve. The liquid was emitting vapors and tested as 1-2 PH indicating the liquid was corrosive coinciding with the lading. All service equipment fittings and closures were found to be properly secured. The product pooled in the bowl of the SRV was absorbed with a chemical pad. The SRV was bubble leak tested externally and was found to be leak free. The shipper of record was notified of the incident. A qualified mobile repair unit will replace the SRV on-site and re-qualify the tank car prior to continuing in transportation. The removed SRV will be sent to the manufacturer for a bench test.
